Article.ArticleTitle: Tanshinone analog inhibits castration-resistant prostate cancer cell growth by inhibiting glycolysis in an AR-dependent manner.

AbstractText: Androgen receptor (AR) is one of the key targets for the treatment of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). Current endocrine therapy can greatly improve patients with CRPC. However, with the change of pathogenic mechanism, acquired resistance often leads to the failure of treatment. Studies have shown that tanshinone IIA (TS-IIA) and its derivatives have significant antitumor activity, and have certain AR-targeting effects, but the mechanism is unknown. In this study, the TS-IIA analog TB3 was found to significantly inhibit the growth of CRPC in vitro and in vivo. Molecular docking, cellular thermal shift assay, and cycloheximide experiments confirmed that AR was the target of TB3 and promoted the degradation of AR. Furthermore, TB3 can significantly inhibit glycolysis metabolism by targeting the AR/PKM2 axis. The addition of pyruvic acid could significantly alleviate the inhibitory effect of TB3 on CRPC cells. Besides, the knockdown of AR or PKM2 also could reverse the effect of TB3 on CRPC cells. Taken together, our study suggests that TS-IIA derivative TB3 inhibits glycolysis to prevent the CRPC process by targeting the AR/PKM2 axis.
